column13: At the time of this report's publication, Infratil and 45% of our portfolio companies have undertaken formal materiality assessments, with the balance of companies leveraging insights from their GRESB material issue weightings. Infratil has built its sustainability strategy on insights from its materiality assessment and applied the findings from the process to develop this report, focusing on the ESG issues that matter to Infratil and our stakeholders.

column7: Governance, Leadership, Climate and Nature, People

All companies have a formalised approach to risk, generally comprising a risk register with identified risks, mitigants and controls. The more mature companies have a complete enterprise risk system and an increasingly formalised approach to climate risk.

Each portfolio company board (or sub-committee) is responsible for monitoring risks, including cyber and data risks, setting policies, and ensuring management has the practices and controls to adhere to them. Further oversight is added through Infratil's Board engagement and direct engagement by Morrison & Co. In the future, this will be supported by Morrison & Co. reviews of portfolio companies' cyber and privacy policies and capabilities related to governance and operations.

Decarbonisation is seen as one such tailwind (a "climate-related opportunity"), and investing in renewable energy is a logical result. Infratil's Board regularly reviews the company's strategy in light of the latest view on megatrends, macroeconomic outlook, and industry tailwinds, including climate change-related ones.

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column13: Following reviews to extend resilience measures, climate-related disaster preparedness, and enhance customer experience, One NZ recently announced a collaboration with SpaceX. Pairing One NZ's award-winning 4G and 5G mobile network with the SpaceX revolutionary satellite constellation will mean, in time, far greater coverage across Aotearoa, New Zealand.

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column7: Welcoming 5.3 million passengers in FY2023, Wellington Airport connects central Aotearoa, New Zealand, with the country's leading centres, regions, eastern Australia, and the Pacific.

column6: Direct economic value generated and distributed
column7: Founded in 2014, Kao Data develops and operates high-performance data centres for advanced computing, with facilities east and west of London and a new facility planned for Manchester.

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: The Sustainable Linked Lending ('SLL') arrangement motivates sustainability actions by linking some of the Airport's lending facilities to sustainability-related targets. Under the arrangement, the Airport has linked $100 million of lending facilities across its major lenders to a series of sustainability targets over four years, with pricing adjusted depending on the company's reported performance against the annual targets.
column20: Sustainable Financing, Linked Lending, Sustainability Targets

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: Under the Too Little, Too Late scenario, a common theme across the platforms is the risk of increased insurance costs and potential negative impacts on availability on attractive commercial terms, as the physical effects of climate change are the most severe under this scenario. We also expect to see higher opex and capex costs as the physical impacts from climate require more maintenance and investment in climate resilience measures.

column6: Financial implications and other risks and opportunities due to climate change
column13: Regarding physical risk, current assessments under scenarios broadly aligned with our transition scenarios indicate that precipitation, heat, and wind are the primary threat exposures for assets in Infratil's portfolio companies. Most assets currently assessed as being exposed to the highest wind risk are, by nature (buildings, clinics, data centres and hydro assets), relatively resilient to this threat across the different scenarios.
column20: Climate Risk Assessment, Physical Risks, Transition Scenarios

column13: Similarly, the recently launched FM Global Resilience Index for countries incorporates "Infrastructure Quality" in its scoring methodology. By investing in sustainable infrastructure that provides the core services society needs, with resilient business models, Infratil has a clear role in supporting systemic resilience through delivering quality infrastructure.

column13: Health and well-being Systems ensure the health and well-being of people living and working in a city. Economy and society: The social and financial systems that enable the urban population to live peacefully and collaborate. Infrastructure and environment: Built and natural systems that provide critical services protect and connect urban citizens. Leadership and strategy: Our cities need informed, inclusive, integrated, and iterative decision-making.

column7: Infratil's after-tax return since listing in March 1994 has been 18.6% per annum, and over the last ten years, 19.4% per annum.
By the end of FY2023, Wellington Airport returned to 90% of pre-pandemic domestic passenger numbers.
For 19 out of the last 20 years, Infratil's rolling 10-year average annual return has been between 10.3% and 29.0%.

column7: Infratil People will not accept bribes, gratuities, or other inducements in their business dealings on behalf of Infratil. "Gifts" and "personal benefits" can include accommodation, goods, services, discounts, special loan terms, etc. Infratil People will not accept gifts or personal benefits of any value from internal or external parties if it could be perceived this could compromise or influence any decision by Infratil, taking into account the perceptions of key stakeholders.
column24: Ethics Policy and Code of Conduct

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: Infratil has always required the highest standards of honesty and integrity from its Directors, the Manager and employees and directors of its Portfolio Entities ("Infratil People"). The ethics policy and code of conduct recognise Infratil's legal and other obligations to Infratil's financial product holders and other stakeholders. The policy applies to Directors and employees and sets the ethical and behavioural standards and professional conduct that Infratil, as an owner, expects the Manager and Portfolio Entities to adopt for their directors and employees.
